content.description: A squeeze and offwidth roof slot.  Get ready to get sideways.
content.protection: W.C. #6B.D. #7 (2× 7's would probably be best)Double length slingDraw
content.location: In between "School Cracks" and "Over the Hill".Recommended to set up a belay under the roof. Double length and a #1 for belay.  (P1) is 3rd class.

content.description: Off-width created by huge flake on the right side of the slab.  When you get to the old anchors, move left onto the slab to finish off.
content.protection: Shares anchor with Nit Nat.  there is a rusty old set of anchors about 60 feet up that can be used as a re-direct, if top-roping.
content.location: Behind flake, to the right of Nit-Nat.

content.description: Low Angle Crack, short but Sweet
content.protection: Little
content.location: Near top of Exposed Granite Formation, Left, Above, & South of One for the Road.

content.description: Start up gulley right of Quaker Oats. Traverse to third bolt on Quaker, to third bolt on Sinkso, to second bolt on Ego Trip, third bolt on Cake Walk, to cracks and up to belay bolts left of Black Death.  Reverse to clean (PG-13) or have second clean. Good practice for leading/seconding a traverse.
content.protection: medium cam or TCU for cracks,  A small piece under the flake in the middle helps the second.

content.description: Parallel wide cracks head diagonally up and right. A gear anchor can be built up top or you can traverse right to the tree and eye bolt that's above the other routes on Sven Slab. A #5 Camelot can be helpful at the beginning for new leaders.
content.protection: standard rack
content.location: The route starts on the far left side of Sven Slab Proper, just to the left of Criss Cross.

content.description: Two boulders stacked on top of each creating a slabby face.  This is a top rope only route.   The anchors (two bolts) can be easily accessed by scrambling up on climber’s right to the top of the boulders.  Look for the boulder with the vertical crack above the student death slab.  There’s a “left face” and a “right face”. Both go at 5.4
content.protection: Two bolt anchor.  No other pro.
content.location: Located just SE of the Hawk Boulder.

content.description: This climb was originally a 3rd class climb, start the route about 10 feet right of i sinkso and climb with typical slab holds on low-grade slab and traverse left a little to belay at a tree with one eyebolt.Jan 3rd, 2021 Update: Screwlinks and chains were added today to the two bolt anchors at the top of the route.  They had been missing for quite some time.10-26-19 Update: There are also two bolts (for belay or rap) with screw links just climbers right of the eye bolt and tree. You can continue up another short pitch of comparable climbing from there for a great view.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 1 eyebolt
content.location: This climb starts on top of a boulder 10 feet right of i sinkso.  On the main sven slab.

content.description: Down and right from Sven Slab. This is the first route you encounter when hiking up the trail. Climb the obvious wide crack with a difficult start.
content.protection: From BD .5-2 singles, double 3 and 4, a couple alpine draws.
content.location: To the right of dark passage and the second route to the left of the giant flake.  This section is the first wall you see when approaching to the main wall.  Down and right from main wall.

content.description: You never get too many powerful overhang lie backing routes in the Mcdowells, and hence why this route is classic for the area. Over the Hill follows Mousetracks beginning but breaks right to the ledge next to the imposing right overhang. You get fantastic gear, and then it's time to go full force, and if not fall cleanly through the air on great gear.
content.protection: Double set from green C3 to #3 Blue C4 Camalot, 1 BD C4 optional  and set of small to medium stoppers. No fixed anchors, all natural pro. We rappelled the route with a 70m to the start of mousetracks.
content.location: Over The Hill shares the same start as Mousetracks but breaks off right toward the closest roof with a right arching crack.

content.description: A really fun route on the looker's left end of Sven Slab. It's an obvious right leaning crack going up the left wall of a gully. Longer than it looks. A very enjoyable pitch, with a crux or two, bomber gear, great easy crack climb. Belay from a tree on a big ledge. A guidebook described a 2nd, pitch, it didn't look worth doing. A quick scramble up and to the right puts you on the ridge and a nice summit. Walk climber's left from the ledge and scramble back to the base to get down.
content.protection: Gear through hands. Be aware you need to place a fair amount of gear to protect from swinging into the gully.
content.location: The last clean rock on the far left hand side of Sven slab.

content.description: Start at the small overhang midway between Changes in Lattitude and the flake. Pleasant slab climbing that gradually increases in difficulty until you reach the first bolt. 5.10 climbing in the vicinity of the second and third bolts. 30 feet of run-out until the chains.
content.protection: Three bolts, with the first bolt about 30 feet above the start, and a two bolt anchor with chains. You could place a cam in the small overhang at the start, but it would be a pointless gesture. The route can be safely top-roped (safer than free soloing to the first bolt).
content.location: In the middle of the slab, 20 feet to the right of Changes in Lattitude.

content.description:
Crux moves on all three pitches for different reasons.  On the first pitch, it is all about clearing the small roof. For the second pitch, there is a tricky start to get into the right arching crack.  The third pitch is a bit difficult to protect due to the crack shape, but it can be done safely. 

  Damon W. adds: Originally done in 2 pitches, but breaking it up into 3 pitches as noted in description will probably decrease rope drag.
content.protection: Tapers, cams from Metolius 1 to BD 6 (for anchoring).
content.location: The next route to the left of Black Death, on the way to One for the Road.

content.description: Slab into easier slab, a bit of crumbly rock and vegetation, meets up with the anchor for Right Chute.
content.protection: 1 bolt & small cams/nuts
content.location: Left of the right chute, right of the dihedral which is to the right of One for the Road

content.description: Climb 15 feet to the first bolt, this is the crux, to make it easier start up on bolder and move slightly to the left.  clip fairly long runouts past two more bolts to and eyebolt belay, there is a second pitch but it is definitely not worth doing, fly if you want to.
content.protection: 3 bolts to 1 eyebolt
content.location: This is the second route to the left when you come into the sven slab main wall, it is left of Quaker oats, Start down from boulder.

climbs.name: Hippity Hop
climbs.fa: Jim Waugh, John Dargis, Dylan Williams

content.description: Climb slot crack to up to an alcove then step out onto face and up along run out bolted line.
content.protection: BD #1-#4 and two bolts.
content.location: This is just right of the huge right angling Nit Nat flake. Go up and over the boulders toward the rock face. Right of the new bolt line, at the obvious slot that goes to a chimney.

content.description: Somewhat thin sven slab climbing.  Most difficult part is first 20 or 30 feet.
content.protection: 3 bolts, one or two very small gear placements possible.  One very large anchor at top behind tree.
content.location: Two to the left of Quaker Oats, start on small boulder

content.description: Begin at the the thin face directly below new bolts. A crimpy and balancy clip for bolt 2. Thin traverse on the face to Hippity-Hop where the route eases considerably.
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor shared with Hippity Hop
content.location: Just left of Hippity Hop, start at the boulder at the corner of the Nit Nat Flake, and transition to the face.

content.description: Climb thin but positive edges past 3 bolts and horizontal crack. Run out with deck potential on first bolt.
content.protection: 3 bolts + medium cam for horizontal. 2 bolt anchor, no chains currenly. Also can walk off or rap from nit nat chains
content.location: Farthest left route in nit nat area left of Peaches and cream

content.description: Great movement on this route with the crux flowing early in the bolt section. You smear and edge on featureless granite through two bolts trending left on a sloping mantle to jug. Plug a cam and move up on easier climbing. Time to place another solid piece in a horizontal crack, and then finish through one bolt to awesome granite rail. Fourth class climbing follows to a great anchor with two rap rings.
content.protection: Three bolts, C4 #3 and #4, plus draws and two longer slings.
content.location: This is located immediately left of Black Death in a nice staging area.

content.description: This route ascends the arete above "one for the road"(oftr). Begin to the left of oftr scramble to ledge then up to a flake (a piece of protection may ease any anxiety) then follow bolts (5) up to a bolted anchor. Rap off.
content.protection: 3/4 camalot before the first bolt is nice, five bolts, bolted anchor at top.
content.location: Left of "one for the road"

content.description: Easy face climb that can be done as one or two pitches (60m rope required for one 185' pitch). Climb face right of bottom belay. 2 bolts at the beginning, horizontal crack part way up for a cam or nut, then 3 more bolts.  A bit run out but climbing is pretty easy (you can place pro over in the gully to the left if you wish).  There is a ledge 2/3 up with a crack where you can break it into two pitches.  Good belay ledge at the top with nice crack for setting up an anchor, or you may be able utilize nearby bushes. Walk off towards the east (rock left).
content.protection: 5 bolts, small to #1 C4, stoppers. Use 24" alpine draws if you plan to climb it as one long pitch.
content.location: Right of One for the Road on the far east portion of the Sven slab area.

climbs.name: Changes in Longitude
climbs.fa: Dan Dingle, Mike Lawson, Alex McGuffie, Brent Roberts, and Maxie McGuffie  1978

content.description:
CIL is a horizontal seam that crosses 2 large boulders to a huge detached flake.  The entire first pitch of the climb is a traverse from left to right; make sure you place a good amount of pro to protect your second.   

  Pitch 1: Start on top of a large boulder and make a thin exposed move to get into the seam under a small roof.  One spicy move and you're at jugs and good feet.  Keep moving right for about 40' until you get to a break in the boulder.  Look right and up 5' and you'll see the seam continue on.  Follow this  for about 30' and arrive at the detached flake to find 2 older, but solid bolts to belay from(semi-hanging, but comfortable). The belay can be backed up by medium sized gear.  

  Pitch 2: Fun, easy chimney climbing up to a large chockstone.  Get past this and head up the face on the left to the top.
content.protection: Set of nuts,  doubles cams from 1/2" - 2"
content.location:
CIL is located about 200 feet west(climbers right) of the base of Quaker Oats.  

  When looking at Sven Slab from the parking area you can see a massive detached flake, this is the location of the end of pitch 1.  Obvious thin seam runs that runs left of the flake across the middle of the boulders is CIL.  Start is the very left side of this seam.

climbs.name: Changes in Lattitude
climbs.fa: Jim Waugh, John Dargis, Dylan Williams 1981

content.description: Climb up positive edges past 3 bolts and horizontal crack to chains. First bolt is high but the climbing is relatively secure if you have some granite slab experience.
content.protection: 3 bolts, medium cam for horizontal, chains shared with nit nat
content.location: Left of nit nat and right of Peaches and cream

content.description: A nice boulder problem with two bolts that extends into runout climbing on easier terrain. If you've done the classics for the Nit Nat area already give Attitudes a go.
content.protection: Two bolts protect the crux section, the climbing after can be protected with small cams or offset nuts. You can protect the crack, but the climbing after goes at run-out 5.4. The climb finishes at a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Changes in Attitude is located right above Dark Passage on a large detached boulder. The climb starts off a small boulder patch to the left. Clip the bolt and get ready for some fun movement.

content.description: climb off of boulder up and left to bolt.  Follow line of bolts over bulge.
content.protection: 4 bolts
content.location: bolt line to the right of Black Death, 4th from Quaker Oats

content.description: Climb up on triangular boulder, place gear, then fire out left for the first bolt. Continue up past short left-facing flake and continue up to second bolt. Continue up face to crack. Get in crack and take that up and right all the way to belay at eyebolt.
content.protection: 2 bolts, pro to 3" or so.
content.location: Far left side of Main slab bolted routes, black H2O stains are a sign near start(or start on triangular boulder). Starts under a right-arching crack. off the triangular boulder..

content.description: Face climb past two bolts to a two bolt anchor.  All hardware has been recently replaced. Crux is mental. Gear can be placed in the chimney on the lower right side if it helps put you at ease. I used a #5.
content.protection: 2 bolt face   3 ish bolts at top
content.location: far lower right end of Svens Slab. It's the one that looks ridiculously like an arrowhead.   Route looks like a few potential starts are available.

content.description: Always & Forever, encapsulates this granite flake spire's ominous feeling. The opening moves off the  deck are powerful, delicate, and slightly mysterious in nature. The starting moves include crimps and sidepulls, then you will encounter the crux proper. High steps, core tension, and finger stack crimps are the name of the game. Finally the route connects back into easier slab climbing, run-out, on Hippity Hop.
content.protection: Bolts through the initial independent line of Always and forever. Runout on easier terrain eventually joining with the bolt on Hippity Hop.
content.location: Left of the alcove that Hippity Hop starts in.

content.description: Sven Slab, so named because a Sven saw was used to cut the original trail up to the wall, is probably the most popular granite climbing location near Phoenix after Pinnacle Peak. This is the place to hone those sturdy foot muscles on thin granite crystal and edge climbing. The main wall is home to several nice moderate outings, while the outrigger crag down to the right features some additional harder lines.
